p:
The vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) isoforms were particularly attractive targets to inhibit angiogenesis
9
,
10 . The expression of VEGF during embryonic stages is high and is thought to play a crucial role in new (vasculogenesis) or pre-existing blood vessels (angiogenesis)
11 . For certain solid tumours, overexpression of VEGF contributes to increased tumour growth and metastasis, which may be attributed to improved nutrient replenishment availability for the metabolising cell
12
,
13 . Vascular endothelial growth factor receptor-2 (VEGFR-2) is a subtype of tyrosine kinase receptor VEGF family (VEGFR-TK)
14
,
15 . It is responsible for normal and abnormal changes in vascular endothelial cells
16
,
17 . VEGFR-2 inhibition will affect tumour cell blood supply, inhibiting its development, proliferation, and metastasis. VEGFR signalling pathway inhibition is a key therapeutic target for tumour inhibition
18
,
19 .
